newsitem.title: USA: Bosnia war crimes judge threatens to quit - report.
newsitem.headline: Bosnia war crimes judge threatens to quit - report.

text.p: The head judge of the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia may quit unless the West within 10 months arrests leaders indicted for crimes against humanity, a newspaper reported.
The Christian Science Monitor reported in Monday's edition that Antonio Cassese made the threat to a University of Connecticut Law School panel in Hartford, Conn., on Saturday.

"If the major powers of the world are not consistent and don't make arrests in the next 10 months, we are prepared to pack up and go home," the Monitor reported. "We think our job is to try leaders, not small fry."
Of the 74 people indicted for war crimes, only seven are in custody, and none are leaders who ordered killings, the Monitor said.

Former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his army commander Gen. Ratko Mladic were indicted by the tribunal and charged with genocide for the slaughter of up to 6,000 Moslems civilians in Srebrenica, but remained free.
Cassese's remarks were apparently sparked by a sugggestion by U.S. human rights official John Shattuck that tribunal officials "be patient."

Cassese, a leading scholar of international law at Italy's Florence University, said if the arrest are not made "we will propose to the Security Council to close down the tribunal," the newspaper said.
